replies.bodyText: It's HTML. If you have an opening tag HTML syntax says you have to have a closing tag
replies.author: Sollace

replies.bodyText: tags do not need a closing tag in HTML (it's one of the automatically inferred closing tags in HTML), and it's especially not part of Yarn's javadoc style.

replies.bodyText: Again missing closing tags!
replies.author: Sollace

replies.bodyText:
Lol no, you need to look at how jdk does it. https://github.com/openjdk/jdk/blob/0f13e2277fe727500949cbe036d236cae0267ac3/src/java.base/share/classes/java/lang/String.java#L87-L94
They don't use closing tags. And it works quite well!
replies.author: liach

replies.bodyText: Regardless, I'm not going to accept broken html into my PRs.
replies.author: Sollace

replies.bodyText:
It's literally not broken HTML.

is one of the tags for which the closing tag is implied if missing. See here for example: https://stackoverflow.com/a/59307920 (this also links to the actual HTML spec part defining this behaviour)
replies.author: Juuxel

replies.bodyText:
From the same stackoverflow question:

[I] would strongly encourage just using both the beginning and end tags everywhere for consistency. It'll also make it easier for when you do decide to start following the XHTML standards.
replies.author: Sollace

replies.bodyText:
Still, using no

tags is the Yarn convention and it should be followed by all PRs. That's how it's done everywhere else in Yarn, and doing it differently here would just clutter the docs and be inconsistent with existing mappings.
replies.author: Juuxel

replies.bodyText:
Imo having

or not is not a big problem. I am against requring

endings, but am not supporting enforcing removal of

either.
